SOC Title: Airline Pilots, Copilots, and Flight Engineers
title_lower: airline pilots, copilots, and flight engineers
SOC Definition: Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft, usually on scheduled air carrier routes, for the transport of passengers and cargo. Requires Federal Air Transport certificate and rating for specific aircraft type used. Includes regional, national, and international airline pilots and flight instructors of airline pilots. Excludes “Electro-Mechanical and Mechatronics Technologists and Technicians” (17-3024).
From Occupation Data: Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft, usually on scheduled air carrier routes, for the transport of passengers and cargo. Requires Federal Air Transport certificate and rating for specific aircraft type used. Includes regional, national, and international airline pilots and flight instructors of airline pilots.
50 highest-paying jobs in America: Airline pilots and copilots do more than navigate aircraft; they also master flight software and maintain flight logs, all while spearheading customer service for hundreds of passengers per day. Flight engineers ensure the safe travel of planes by monitoring instruments and other information, though the job is disappearing. Pilots must complete training and pass medical exams to be cleared to take off.
Stacker Description: Airline pilots command commercial aircraft on scheduled routes, safely transporting millions of passengers and cargo worldwide. These highly trained professionals must obtain a Federal Air Transport certificate and aircraft-specific ratings. Beyond technical flying skills, they coordinate with air traffic control, monitor weather conditions, and make critical decisions that ensure passenger safety throughout every flight.

SOC Definition: Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft on nonscheduled air carrier routes, or helicopters. Requires Commercial Pilot certificate. Includes charter pilots with similar certification, and air ambulance and air tour pilots. Excludes regional, national, and international airline pilots. Excludes “Electro-Mechanical and Mechatronics Technologists and Technicians” (17-3024).
From Occupation Data: Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft on nonscheduled air carrier routes, or helicopters. Requires Commercial Pilot certificate. Includes charter pilots with similar certification, and air ambulance and air tour pilots. Excludes regional, national, and international airline pilots.
50 highest-paying jobs in America: To become a commercial airplane or helicopter pilot, a trainee must obtain a commercial pilot certificate from the Federal Aviation Administration. Airline pilots also need an Airline Transport Pilot certificate. Commercial pilots can also become instructors and teach others using simulators and dual-controlled aircraft.
Highest-paying jobs for high school grad: For anyone who dreams of taking flight, a career as a commercial pilot might be the right choice. Aspiring commercial pilots must log at least 250 hours of flight experience, hold a second-class medical certificate, pass the Federal Aviation Administration written exam, complete additional flight training, and pass a checkflight to earn their license. Unlike airline pilots, commercial pilots might also fly helicopters, cargo planes, or backcountry flights.
Stacker Description: Commercial pilots fly aircraft for specialized services beyond regular airline routes, including charter flights, air ambulances, tourism, and cargo delivery. Unlike airline pilots, they often work for smaller companies and may pilot helicopters or smaller fixed-wing aircraft. These pilots must hold a Commercial Pilot certificate and adapt to diverse flying conditions and mission requirements.

SOC Definition: Control air traffic on and within vicinity of airport, and movement of air traffic between altitude sectors and control centers, according to established procedures and policies. Authorize, regulate, and control commercial airline flights according to government or company regulations to expedite and ensure flight safety.
From Occupation Data: Control air traffic on and within vicinity of airport, and movement of air traffic between altitude sectors and control centers, according to established procedures and policies. Authorize, regulate, and control commercial airline flights according to government or company regulations to expedite and ensure flight safety.
50 highest-paying jobs in America: Air traffic controllers ensure that aircraft maintain safe distances, issue landing and takeoff instructions, and inform pilots of weather hazards. There are several paths to becoming a controller, including earning degrees offered by the Federal Aviation Administration's Air Traffic Collegiate Training Initiative. Three years of work experience in the field is also considered a qualifier for a job as an air traffic controller.
Stacker Description: Air traffic controllers orchestrate the complex choreography of aircraft movement in and around airports and through designated airspace sectors. They authorize takeoffs and landings, guide pilots through safe flight paths, and coordinate between different control centers. Their split-second decisions and clear communication prevent collisions and maintain the efficiency of the national airspace system.

SOC Definition: Ensure the safe takeoff and landing of commercial and military aircraft. Duties include coordination between air-traffic control and maintenance personnel, dispatching, using airfield landing and navigational aids, implementing airfield safety procedures, monitoring and maintaining flight records, and applying knowledge of weather information.
From Occupation Data: Ensure the safe takeoff and landing of commercial and military aircraft. Duties include coordination between air-traffic control and maintenance personnel, dispatching, using airfield landing and navigational aids, implementing airfield safety procedures, monitoring and maintaining flight records, and applying knowledge of weather information.
Highest-paying jobs for high school grad: When a plane is coming in for landing or getting ready for takeoff, airfield operations specialists are the professionals who ensure everything runs smoothly. That includes coordinating with air traffic control and on-the-ground maintenance workers, implementing safety procedures, keeping flight records, and monitoring the weather. As states with some of the largest airports, California and Texas employ the largest numbers of airfield operations specialists in the country.
Stacker Description: Airfield operations specialists ensure airports run smoothly and safely behind the scenes. They coordinate between air traffic control and maintenance crews, dispatch aircraft, monitor navigational equipment, and maintain detailed flight records. These professionals also implement safety procedures and apply weather information to support safe aircraft operations on the ground and during critical takeoff and landing phases.

SOC Definition: Monitor safety of the aircraft cabin. Provide services to airline passengers, explain safety information, serve food and beverages, and respond to emergency incidents.
From Occupation Data: Monitor safety of the aircraft cabin. Provide services to airline passengers, explain safety information, serve food and beverages, and respond to emergency incidents.
Highest-paying jobs for high school grad: Although flight attendants must be certified by the Federal Aviation Administration, they don't need a college degree to do their jobs. The 10-year forecast for flight attendant jobs predicts a growth rate of about 10%, but that doesn't account for the sharp decrease in the number of airline passengers and subsequent business turbulence that airlines faced during the COVID-19 pandemic. Executives and investors remain cautious about the recovery of the industry.
Stacker Description: Flight attendants serve as the primary safety professionals in aircraft cabins, trained to handle everything from routine service to life-threatening emergencies. While they're known for serving meals and beverages, their primary responsibility involves passenger safety through pre-flight demonstrations, emergency response, and maintaining order during flights. They must complete rigorous safety training and regular recertification.

SOC Title: Ambulance Drivers and Attendants, Except Emergency Medical Technicians

They safely transport individuals to and from medical facilities, assist with loading and unloading patients, and ensure passenger comfort during transit.
